items.title: Watch: ‘Daphne Tours’ Would Promote Her Cause Worldwide, Irish Tourist Moved By Her Story Says
items.author: Ana Tortell
items.description:
>

An Irish national holidaying in Malta stopped by yesterday’s protest against the government’s handling of the Vitals scandal and gave his two cents on what’s going on. Rory O’Driscoll explained to Lovin Malta that he had read Paul Caruana Galizia’s book, A Death in Malta, and was shocked to arrive on the island and be …
items.content:
>

An Irish national holidaying in Malta stopped by yesterday’s protest against the government’s handling of the Vitals scandal and gave his two cents on what’s going on.

Rory O’Driscoll explained to Lovin Malta that he had read Paul Caruana Galizia’s book, A Death in Malta, and was shocked to arrive on the island and be given the impression that “things haven’t changed at all”.

“That deeply upset us.”

This was Rory’s first time in Malta, he told the newsroom while standing ahead of the Great Siege monument in Valletta that is decorated with images, candles, and flowers in honour of Daphne Caruana Galizia.

“I would hope that there’s a bigger monument to her going forward, and I hope that this stays there,” he said while pointing at Daphne’s

>A post shared by Lovin Malta (@lovinmalta)

When asked about what shocked him the most about what’s going on after noting that, despite not being Maltese, he clearly was informed and following local news, he responded “I just worry, is the whole system corrupt in Malta or is it not? Is it a mafia state or is it not? That’s my worry.”

Rory explained that he was deeply moved by Caruana Galizia’s story, even hoping to find some sort of tour of Daphne’s life and her place of birth, saying that this would promote her cause worldwide.

He and his wife even went to the Mosta church in an attempt to visit her burial site, but soon discovered that just her funeral was held there.

A protest was held yesterday against the government’s handling of the turmoil that resulted from the Vitals scandal. During the demonstration, hundreds of people chanted “kellha raġun” (she was right) while holding up photos of the assassinated journalist.

Do you think that tours in Daphne’s name should be organised to raise more awareness on her important story?

•

items.title: 5 Reasons To Boost Your Brand With Lovin Malta
items.author: Lovin Malta
items.description:

Lovin Malta is not just about sharing news; we’re about making connections. Here are five reasons why Lovin Malta is your go-to for local marketing success: 1. Extensive Reach Need to get the …
items.content:
>

Lovin Malta is not just about sharing news; we’re about making connections. We link the biggest audience across Malta and Gozo directly to your brand, making sure every campaign with us is something special.

Here are five reasons why Lovin Malta is your go-to for local marketing success:

1. Extensive Reach

Need to get the word out? We’ve got you covered. With the largest digital audience in Malta and Gozo, we ensure your message reaches every corner—from the bustling local markets to the tranquil coastlines.

2. Engaged Audiences

We’re all about sparking conversations and building relationships. Our content doesn’t just get seen; it gets talked about, making your brand a part of daily conversation in Malta.

>A post shared by Lovin Malta (@lovinmalta)

3. Diverse Advertising Options

Whether it’s a catchy article, a heartfelt video, or a strategic social media post, we have all the tools to bring your brand to life. We’re here to help you create campaigns that resonate and inspire.

4. Smart Insights

With our finger on the pulse of what works, we use the latest trends to fine-tune your marketing efforts. Our insights help you understand the market better, so you can make smarter decisions about how to engage your audience.

5. Trusted by the Community

People turn to Lovin Malta because they trust us to deliver content that matters. When we introduce them to your brand, they listen, because they know we bring them the best of what’s around.

>A post shared by Lovin Malta (@lovinmalta)

Ready to make your brand a household name? Team up with us at Lovin Malta, where your next big audience is just one campaign away. Reach out now, and let’s start on a journey that leads to lasting business success.

>Get in touch today. Your audience awaits!

•

items.title: 11-Year-Old Maltese Boy Publishes Third Book To Shed Light On Autism
items.author: Tim Diacono
items.description: Beppe Caruana may only be 11 years old but he has just published his third children’s book, one which he hopes will help people better understand his autism.
items.content: Beppe Caruana may only be 11 years old but he has just published his third children’s book, one which he hopes will help people better understand his autism.

items.title: Art that oscillates between the poetic and the political
items.description: Trevor Borg is one of four local artists whose work is being exhibited in the national pavilion forming part of the Malta Biennale. Here he sits with Daniel Xerri to discuss the political dimension of his work and how it engages with such issues as the loss of cultural heritage.

items.title: Malta’s GDP to grow 6.8% in 2022, slowing down to 3.5-3.7% in following 3 years
items.description: Malta’s gross domestic product (GDP) is projected to grow by 6.8% this year, and by 3.7% in 2023, followed by growth rates of 3.6% and 3.5% in 2024 and 2025, respectively, the Central Bank of Malta said Friday.
items.content: Malta’s gross domestic product (GDP) is projected to grow by 6.8% this year, and by 3.7% in 2023, followed by growth rates of 3.6% and 3.5% in 2024 and 2025, respectively, the Central Bank of Malta said Friday.

items.title: EU leaders seek to stand up to US and avoid trade war
items.description: European Union leaders sought ways Thursday to stand up to the United States over its new green technologies plan that they say unfairly discriminates against Washington's best global ally and demanded the same concessions as American free trade partners Canada and Mexico.
items.content: European Union leaders sought ways Thursday to stand up to the United States over its new green technologies plan that they say unfairly discriminates against Washington's best global ally and demanded the same concessions as American free trade partners Canada and Mexico.
